document_title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
summary_full: This study investigated the potential of electrical impedance myography (EIM) to detect muscle atrophy caused by spaceflight and hind limb unloading (HLU) in mice. Researchers compared EIM measurements of ex vivo gastrocnemius muscle from mice that underwent spaceflight (STS-135) or HLU for 13 days against their respective ground controls. They also assessed muscle fiber size and bone mineral density (aBMD). Results showed that both spaceflight and HLU led to significant reductions in the multifrequency phase-slope parameter of EIM, which correlated with decreased muscle fiber size and hind limb aBMD. These findings suggest EIM is a promising tool for monitoring muscle disuse in microgravity or immobilization scenarios.
key_findings: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading (HLU) in mice both caused significant reductions in the multifrequency phase-slope parameter of electrical impedance myography (EIM).
The observed EIM changes correlated with reduced muscle fiber size in spaceflight mice.
EIM phase-slope parameter also correlated with hind limb areal bone mineral density (aBMD) in both spaceflight and HLU groups.
HLU mice showed a significant reduction in gastrocnemius muscle mass compared to controls.
Spaceflight mice exhibited smaller average muscle fiber cross-sectional areas compared to ground controls.
future_research_fields: Longitudinal in vivo EIM measurements to monitor muscle changes during spaceflight.
Correlation of in vivo EIM data with in vivo bone mass and ex vivo muscle histology.
Functional testing of muscle units to relate dynamic changes to EIM data.
Development of dedicated muscle impedance-measuring devices for enhanced sensitivity.
Investigation into the potential contribution of water shifts or dehydration to EIM changes.

conclusions: Electrical impedance myography (EIM) shows significant alterations in mouse gastrocnemius muscle following spaceflight and hind limb unloading, mirroring changes seen in other studies of disuse. These EIM changes correlate with muscle fiber size and bone mineral density, supporting EIM's potential as a non-invasive tool for assessing muscle disuse in microgravity or immobilization.
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that electrical impedance myography can effectively detect muscle atrophy caused by spaceflight and unloading, offering a potential non-invasive method for monitoring astronaut health and aiding in the development of countermeasures for musculoskeletal deconditioning.
